I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide a concessional loan of $30 million from 
its ordinary capital resources for subprogram 2 of the Financial Market Development Program.1 
The  program  supports  key  policy  reforms  designed  to  address  identified  deficiencies, 
vulnerabilities and inadequate inclusiveness in the finance sector and is aimed to strengthen the 
finance sector’s resource mobilization to improve its allocation efficiency and to enhance stability 
and inclusiveness.   
 
2.  Subprogram 2 will build on the reforms achieved under subprogram 1 through continued 
(i) development of nonbank financial systems, (ii) strengthening of the stability and integrity of the 
financial  system,  and  (iii)  promotion  of  financial  inclusion.  The  program’s  impacts  are 
macroeconomic stability achieved, economic diversity and productive capacity enhanced, and 
poverty eradicated and inequality reduced, following Bhutan’s Twelfth Five Year Plan, 2018–
2023.2 The effect of the reform under the program is the stability, efficiency, and inclusiveness of 
the finance sector enhanced.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The economy remains vulnerable to economic volatility because of the country’s small 
size, narrow economic base, limited connectivity, and susceptibility to climate change and natural 
disasters. While Bhutan averaged 7.0% of rapid economic growth from fiscal year (FY) 1988 to 
FY2018, hydropower was the economy’s main driver, contributing 25.0% to its gross domestic 
product. The country’s lack of diversification does not provide adequate job opportunities for the 
growing young population entering the labor market. The government’s Twelfth Five Year Plan, 
2018–2023 aims to diversify the economy by creating jobs and promoting the private sector. 
However, private sector development is constrained by inadequate access to finance and the high 
cost of obtaining credit.  
 
4.  Well-functioning financial markets with strong institutions, transparent legal structures, 
and rules and regulations with the ability to accommodate the latest requirements of electronic 
commerce would assist in better financial inclusion. Subprogram 2 will continue to support the 
government in its commitment to continue reforms to make the finance sector more responsive 
to the country’s emerging priorities.  
  
5.  This technical assistance (TA) is necessary to undertake the reforms under the program 
by helping to make the finance sector more responsive to the government’s emerging priorities, 
while remaining stable and inclusive. The proposed TA3 will help the government strengthen 
regulations and guidelines to implement the reforms under subprogram 3, build the capacity of 
the government agencies and financial institutions to implement the reforms, provide training and 
capacity building to entrepreneurs and the disadvantaged to promote financial inclusion, and 
conduct public awareness activities on the reforms for greater adaptability of the proposed 
reforms.   
  
 
1  ADB. 2019. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Programmatic

2  Government of Bhutan, Gross National Happiness Commission. 2018. Twelfth Five Year Plan, 2018–2023. Thimphu.

B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  The TA will support the completion of the program’s three outputs: (i) nonbank financial 
systems  developed,  (ii)  stability  and  integrity  of  the  financial  system  strengthened,  and 
(iii) financial inclusion promoted. It will be implemented over 15 months from December 2020 to 
March 2022. The TA will engage 15 person-months of international consultancy services and 
13 person-months  of  national  consultancy  services.  The  consultants  will  work  closely  with 
stakeholders, including ADB, to undertake the activities that are aligned with the program and are 
primarily designed to support the government in achieving institutional measures to complete the 
reform agenda. 
 
7.  Output 1: Nonbank financial systems developed. The TA will support the executing 
and implementing agencies in the following ways: 
(i)  the Royal Monetary Authority (RMA) to formulate listing rules for government 
bonds and bills; 
(ii)  the  RMA  to  create  revised  regulations  on  the  listing  of  equity  issuance  by 
companies, including trading market regulations, market trade reporting standards, 
and listing standards; 
(iii)  the Office of the Registrar to formulate corporate governance and corporate social 
responsibility regulations for the adoption of all debt and equity issuers; 
(iv)  the Ministry of Works and Human Settlement to prepare an affordable housing 
finance strategy; 
(v)  the RMA board to develop an insurance industry strategy; and 
(vi)  the RMA to formulate a strategy on the securitization of finance sector assets. 
 
8.  Output 2: Stability and integrity of the financial system strengthened. The TA will 
support entities in the following ways: 
(i)  the RMA to formulate revised rules and regulations on anti-money laundering and 
financial intelligence for all financial institutions in Bhutan; 
(ii)  the RMA to strengthen risk-based monitoring based on the Basel II guidelines of 
the finance sector, including formulating guidelines on stress testing, completing 
stress testing of all five commercial banks, insurance companies, and formulating 
revised corporate governance rules and regulations; 
(iii)  the RMA board to create rules and regulations for a trade receivable discounting 
system; 
(iv)  the RMA board to develop amended foreign exchange rules and regulations; 
(v)  the  RMA  to  implement  the  adoption  of  the  International  Financial  Reporting 
Standards (IFRS) 9 in financial institutions; and 
(vi)  the RMA board to form the policy on centralized data warehouse and data analytics. 
 
9.  Output 3: Financial inclusion promoted. The TA will help 
(i)  the RMA board to formulate rules and regulations on warehouse receipt financing; 
(ii)  the RMA to design an inclusive green finance strategy to promote access to 
finance for entrepreneurs seeking funding for environment-friendly projects; and 
(iii)  the RMA to design the financial technology regulatory sandbox. 
 
10.  Output 4: Awareness building. The TA will continue to provide awareness building 
activities and trainings for stakeholders to promote greater acceptability and compliance with the 
proposed reforms.

3 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $525,000, of which (i) $250,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) and (ii) $250,000 by the Financial 
Sector  Development  Partnership  Special  Fund.4 The  key  expenditure  items  are  listed  in 
Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transport, and other in-
kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants; and procure goods.
